ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A methodological approach to modern Japanese history and an overview of most recent English literature in this field.
Deepened knowledge of modern Japanese history.
Read major works on modern Japanese history; learned about recent approaches to the big issues in the field.
Japanese history with various topics that I have not learned about

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The reading list is very helpful and the assignments are well positioned for graduate students training. I hope some of the assignments could be accomplished cumulatively through the semester as opposed to be all designated towards the end.

Strengths: good selection of readings, Prof. Botsman good at leading discussion and came away always with some new insights and perspectives Weaknesses: maybe would have been better to force the completion of assignments throughout the term instead of mostly at the end.
book presentations and in-class discussions are very helpful

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: High recommended for all historians on Japan or modern East Asia.
Yes, Professor Botsman makes this course fun and informative.
Yes, I think it is a useful course for getting a sense of the field.
Yes. The class is organized well and the content is useful
